title: Freddie Mercury's former lover recalls 'distressing last days as body weakened'
text:

Freddie Mercury's former lover and long-time partner Mary Austin, has spoken about his last days in a revealing unearthed interview.

The Queen singer died in 1991, aged 45, due to complications from AIDS and Mary has recalled the final days they spent together at his Kensington mansion, after he had stopped taking his medication.

She said it was "distressing" to see Freddie deteriorate as his body weakened.

In an interview with OK! Magazine from 2000, Mary said that Freddie made the decision to stop medicating himself and how this had an immediate effect.

(Image: Getty Images)

Mary said: "It was Freddie's decision to finally end it all. He chose the time to die.

“He knew it was coming. The quality of his life had changed so dramatically and he was in more pain every day."

Mary recalled that this brought on a number of complications as Freddie's health nosedived.

(Image: Getty Images)

She continued: "He was losing his sight. His body became weaker as he suffered mild fits.

“It was so distressing to see him deteriorating in this way. One day he decided enough was enough and stopped all the medical supplements that were keeping him going.”

Mary said that she was 'overwhelmed' at how Freddie looked death in the eye and his bravery at that point.

(Image: EX)

Recalling that time, she said: "He looked death in the face and said, ‘Fine, I'll accept it now - I'll go.’

“But it was peaceful and he died with a smile on his face.”

Freddie ensured that Mary was taken care of financially after he was gone, leaving her the mansion and future sales of Queen songs but she said that it took her a long time to come to terms with his passing.

(Image: Alan Davidson/REX/Shutterstock)

She remembered: "Suddenly, there wasn't anyone to help me.

“It made me realise that I wasn't as self-sufficient as I would have liked to have been.

“He was always very protective of me. I only realised, after he died, quite how protective he'd been.

(Image: Richard Young/REX/Shutterstock)

“If something happened, he'd say, ‘Oh darling, don't worry - we'll get over that. He was uplifting."

There were moments though, when Freddie's vulnerability meant that he struggled.

She continued: "At other times, when he was aware he had AIDS and only had a limited time to live, there'd be the odd serious conversation when he'd say to me, ‘Let's go and sit, we don't know how long we have.’”

description: Mary Austin opened up in an unearthed interview in which she detailed the singer's last days after he stopped taking medication
